so there's a redirect to login with Amazon where the user provides their Amazon credentials and ultimately that

the authentication token is short-lived so for security purposes that authentication token is only valid for
one hour so what we also give you is something called a refresh token and so after an hour is up you go and you
request a fresh refresh token and a fresh authentication token using that refresh token and that kind of keeps you
know if that key happens to get compromised for whatever reason it's only valid for one hour and then it expires and you have to go fetch a new

the basics of an abs request you create an HTTP request you set up the HTTP headers you collect the audio from that

know we we take a lot of pride in making sure that the end users are comfortable with the Alexa experience for example

listening and we're encouraging and asking very strongly of our ABS users
and our ABS developers not to store any of the audio locally in order to build

how you process those directives and so

pushing a button on a device or you're pushing a button on your on your mobile device and you're speaking relatively
close to the microphone and depending on where you are relative to the microphone
on the device and what's going on in the background there are actually different speech models that we can apply to the

that's the model that Alexa expect expecting to compare to when she looks
